G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 11\u201315F.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §§ 11–15F and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action for money damages arising from Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is therefore proper in the Lowell District Court. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Substantial and ongoing mold growth in an interior bathroom without a window is inconsistent with the requirements of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.482 (ventilation) and provisions requiring landlords to maintain dwellings in a condition free from chronic dampness and conditions that may endanger or impair the health or safety of an occupant.

105 C.M.R. 410.482 (ventilation).proposition: Substantial and ongoing mold growth in an interior bathroom without a window is inconsistent with the requirements of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.482 (ventilation) and provisions requiring landlords to maintain dwellings in a condition free from chronic dampness and conditions that may endanger or impair the health or safety of an occupant.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: To the extent applicable, Plaintiff also invokes her protection from retaliatory conduct under G.L. c. 186, § 18, and notes that landlord burdens arising from code violations and conditions affecting health and safety cannot be shifted to a tenant by blaming ordinary, reasonable use of the premises.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6C;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law is implied in every residential lease and protects tenants from substantial interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses the “implied covenant of quiet enjoyment” and holds that it was violated where tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment by noise from a lounge the landlords permitted and could control. The opinion treats the covenant as implied in the leases and as protecting tenants against substantial interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts, omissions, or permitted conditions, even absent an intent to evict. This directly supports the stated proposition under Massachusetts law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law is implied in every residential lease and protects tenants from substantial interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly describes the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy and analyzes a statutory quiet enjoyment claim in a residential lease context. It states that the covenant shields tenants from acts or omissions by the landlord that substantially impair the character and value of the leasehold, and applies that standard to interference arising from third-party criminal activity where the landlord allegedly failed to act. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant is implied in residential leases and protects against substantial landlord-caused interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”}

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: A landlord may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment not only by affirmative acts but also by omissions and neglect that result in conditions substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that it covers “acts or omissions” that impair the character and value of the premises. It further ties G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language to this common‑law doctrine, making clear that liability can arise from a landlord’s failure to act to prevent unsanitary, flooding conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment. Thus, the case supports the proposition that omissions and neglect, not just affirmative acts, may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Al Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: A landlord may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment not only by affirmative acts but also by omissions and neglect that result in conditions substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Al Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that negligent omissions, such as a landlord’s failure to repair known defects, can violate the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court states that a landlord may be liable under § 14 for “some degree of fault,” and notes that failure to repair defects of which the landlord has notice is an omission frequently deemed to violate § 14. This squarely supports the proposition that breaches may arise not only from affirmative acts but also from neglect resulting in substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Al Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to correct the mold and the underlying ventilation and moisture problems in a windowless bathroom constitutes a serious interference with the conditions of habitability and with Plaintiff’s safe use of the bathroom and, by extension, the apartment as a whole.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion is a concurring/dissenting discussion about implied warranty of habitability and the effect of housing code violations on rent liability in general. It does not mention mold, ventilation, moisture, or a windowless bathroom, nor does it classify any such condition as a “serious interference” with habitability or safe use of an apartment. The case provides general framework for using sanitary code violations to assess habitability but does not supply specific authority for the proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit … which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions. It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct unsanitary or unsafe conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code and materially affect health and safety may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion acknowledges that the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on the poor conditions, but the Supreme Judicial Court does not analyze or affirm any legal rule tying State Sanitary Code violations or unsanitary/unsafe conditions to a breach of quiet enjoyment. The discussion and holding focus instead on the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability (and related c. 93A issues), expressly noting that no damages were awarded on the quiet-enjoyment claim to avoid duplication. Thus, the case is not real authority for the specific proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct unsanitary or unsafe conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code and materially affect health and safety may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations only in the context of a warranty of habitability claim and the extent of rent abatement, not as a basis for a covenant of quiet enjoyment claim. There is no analysis or holding that a landlord’s failure to correct unsanitary or unsafe code-violating conditions constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
“Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
… Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability…”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Moreover, Massachusetts law recognizes that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary and safe conditions that affect the tenant’s health can give rise to statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does involve a landlord’s failure to maintain habitable, safe premises and applies G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not frame the damages as arising from conditions "that affect the tenant’s health" or as statutory damages specifically for health-related harm. Instead, the Court treats the leaking roof as an interference with quiet enjoyment and clarifies that § 14 provides for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, without discussing health impacts as a predicate. Thus, the opinion supports that § 14 provides statutory damages for interference with quiet enjoyment, not specifically that Massachusetts law recognizes statutory damages for unsanitary/unsafe conditions affecting health.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
The judge further ruled that the leaks in the roof (but not the defective floors) interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. Because of this interference, and based on his reading of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the judge ruled that the plaintiff was entitled to an additional $5,358, three times her monthly rent obligation ($47) for each month during which the leaky roof was unrepaired...

Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference "with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises") shall "be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater…"

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the mold condition and underlying ventilation defect is a “direct or indirect interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14, even absent an express intent to disturb Plaintiff’s rights.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet enjoyment provision to impose liability based on the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences of that conduct, not on any express intent to disturb the tenant’s rights. It holds that failure to provide an essential service (heat) that seriously impairs the premises is a breach of quiet enjoyment regardless of intent, which directly supports using § 14 to reach a landlord’s failure to remedy a serious condition like mold/ventilation defects without proving specific intent to interfere.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment…. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”
